business.start.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Drake-Brockman) took the chair at 3 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: Has the Minister for Repatriation seen a letter circulated to all members of the Parliament by the State President of the Victorian branch of the Returned Services League of 65.000 members in which the State President protests against the repatriation provisions of the Budget and requests a supplementary budget to correct the position; points out that pension values in comparison with the Commonwealth basic wage are now at an all time low; draws attention to the unreasonableness of expecting totally and permanently incapacitated men returning from Vietnam to exist for the rest of their lives on compensation that is less than the basic wage; and expresses the League's disappointment that the Government has not acceded to the request for repatriation hospitalisation for men of the First World War and Boer War? If so, will the Minister comment on the matters raised? If not, will he comment at a later stage if I let him have a copy of the letter?

- I have not seen the letter referred to by the honorable senator. From what I know of it. It is in keeping with a similar letter that was written by the National Executive of the Returned Services League to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister himself will be sending a letter in reply to the letter that was sent to him. Regarding the other aspects that the honorable senator raised, I point out to him, first of all, that during the discussions on a bill in respect of which I gave notice today that I will introduce tomorrow, these matters were considered, and he wilt see that some valuable additions have been made with respect to repatriation not only in relation to pensions but also in relation to repatriation services in Australia for the next 12 months. The honorable senator mentioned totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners. These pensioners will receive an increase amounting to $2 per week. The other matters that the honorable senator mentioned will coma up during the course of the debate on tha bill that I will introduce tomorrow.

- I desire to ask a question of the Minister representing the Acting Prime Minister. Is the Minister aware that in Adelaide on the evening of Friday, 9th September, two students who were engaged in an anti-Vietnam demonstration in front of the United States Consulate set fire to and destroyed a copy of the American flag? Does the Minister know whether the South Australian State Government has made or intends to make an apology to the American Consul on behalf of the Australian community? Is it not a fact that the accepted custom in such circumstances is for the national Government to make an apology also? Does the Australian Government intend to make an apology to the United States Consul on behalf of the great majority of Australians who have been disturbed by this irresponsible and discourteous action directed against an official representative of a friendly country? Have the two students concerned in the flag burning incident been charged by the South Australian police or do the Commonwealth police intend to instigate charges?

- I am sure that all honorable senators will agree that this was a most regrettable and irresponsible act on the part of the students concerned. I think the rest of the question is of such importance that I should ask the honorable senator to place it on the notice paper. If he does that I will ask the Prime Minister to reply to it.

- I direct a question to the Minister in Charge of Commonwealth Activities in Education and Research. Is it true that Spanish fleas are to be imported for the purpose of providing a more effective spreading of myxomatosis among rabbits? If it is, what safeguards are to be provided to ensure that these fleas do not assume plague proportions?

- I am afraid that offhand I am not quite au fait with whether or not any fleas are to be imported or what the nationality of such fleas might be. I certainly will make inquiries so that I can tell the honorable senator whether they will be imported and, if so, of what kind they will be. However, I would be sure that in studying this perhaps elusive problem the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation would do as it always does and take plenty of steps and make plenty of tests to ensure that anything brought into this country was not liable to spread and, in turn, become a pest. I think I had better obtain from the C.S.I.R.O. a written answer to the question. I will do as f have done before in respect of questions asked by the honorable senator.

- Is the Acting Minister for External Affairs in a position to inform the Senate of the result of the elections in South Vietnam? Can he also tell us what percentage cf the eligible voters actually cast their votes; whether the poll was compulsory; and whether the Communist Vietcong attempted to interfere with voters exercising their democratic rights?

- I could not give the honorable senator any precise details of the number of South Vietnamese who cast their votes in the election. The figure would be between 75 and 85 per cent. I would need to do more checking before I could give the figure exactly. I believe that that is a pretty extraordinary result and a pretty extraordinary turnout of voters, considering, as the honorable senator knows, that every effort was made, by terrorism and murder, to prevent South Vietnamese going to the polls to cast their votes for an assembly to draft a constitution. I was asked whether the Vietcong attempted to interfere with voters. Not only did they attempt to interfere with voters and to sabotage the election before it took place, but on the day on which it took place they killed about 30 South Vietnamese who desired to cast their votes, and wounded 167 South Vietnamese. The fact that such a high proportion of South Vietnamese did go to the polls in spite of this risk of death is a pretty strong indication of their feelings and their wish to express those feelings in a free ballot in their country.

- Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware that coal exports to Japan, which are worth $40 million a year to Australia, are threatened by proposed freight increases by the New South Wales Government? Is it true, as stated by the Premier of that State, that the increases in freight charges, which could adversely affect all Australians, are necessary because of injustices to New South Wales in the Budget introduced by the Commonwealth Government? Can the Minister tell us the facts of this case? Who is the responsible or guilty party - the Commonwealth Government or the New South Wales Government?

- I read that the New South Wales Government was to go into conference with the coal exporters on this matter. The exporters had stated that they felt that an increase in rail freights would prejudice the opportunities for the export of coal to Japan. I believe that this conference, if it has not taken place, is about to take place. I understand that the increase in the basic wage, which has a great effect upon the costs of the railways, was largely responsible for the increase in freight rates, and that that was one of the main reasons why the New South Wales Government increased its rail freights.

I desire to ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for the Army. The Minister on 16th March promised to give me an answer to a question regarding national service training, if an answer was available. As I have not yet received such an answer, I now ask: What steps have been taken to provide an answer and when may I expect it?

I understand that this matter formed the basis of a complaint by Senator Cavanagh last night. Before I answer this question, I inform the honorable senator that there was another question which Senator Turnbull asked of me as Minister representing the Minister for the Army. On two or three occasions I have reminded the Department of the Army that this question has not been answered—indeed the last occasion was no later than yesterday morning. I understand that the answer to that question could be given tomorrow. Senator Cavanagh's earlier question referred to members of the Eureka Youth League. I said in reply to the question when it was asked—

quote.para: I do not know the answer to the honorable senator's question, but I shall make inquiries of the Minister for the Army and, if an answer is available, I shall provide it for the honorable senator.

answer.para: The next step taken was the one that is always taken. I referred the question to the Minister for the Army. He was of the opinion that no answer was needed. Con sequently, in view pf that, Senator Cavanagh did not receive any further reply from me. I want to make it clear that in this case, as in every other case, I carried out what I promised to do. That is what I have done in the past and what I will do in the future.

I think that Senator Cavanagh also stated last night that on several occasions Ministers had said that they would try to get replies for the senators asking the questions, but that the senators had not heard anything further from the Ministers. The position is that when I undertake to do that, the answer is given to the senator who asked the question. It does not appear in " Hansard ". If honorable senators are not satisfied with this procedure, I suggest that the remedy is to place the questions on notice and then they will be answered. It is as simple as that.

talk.start.para: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for National Development. Has the Minister seen reports of a find of mineralised ore in the Northern Territory? What costs have been incurred by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Bureau of Mineral Resources in finding this ore? Has the find been made upon land which is owned and controlled by the Commonwealth Government? Do the C.S.I.R.0. and the Bureau of Mineral Resources, or does either of them, intend the to continue to explore these deposits? Is it intention of the Commonwealth Government to develop the ore deposits itself or does it intend to hand them over to private enterprise? If the Government intends to hand over the development of the deposits to private enterprise, will private enterprise pay to the Commonwealth Government the costs of the exploration?

I have read that the Bureau of Mineral Resources has been engaged in endeavouring to find additional deposits of uranium in the Rum Jungle area. At one time there was quite a uranium find there, but it has been worked out. The Bureau has found these additional mineral deposits which, as yet, have not been proved to any extent. It looks as though they will be rich deposits, but the work is only in the very initial stages at the moment. I understand from what I have read that the deposits have quite a considerable zinc content. Exploration is continuing and, of course, will be continued by the Bureau of Mineral Resources. I suggest to the honor able senator that he place the other aspects of his question on the notice paper and t will obtain a correct answer for him. I could tell the honorable senator now what I think to be the position, but that is not what he requires. J am sure that he requires more formal notice of the Government's intentions.

I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Industry. Yesterday during the debate in the Senate on the Trade Practices Bill references were made to statements by the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Shipping and Transport in May last inviting applications from shipping organisations in respect of bulk cargo, to be considered by the Government. I ask whether any information is available as to applications that have been made and whether the subject matter of the applications is some special benefit under the coastal clauses of the Navigation Act. If that information is not available, will the Minister put it before the Senate as soon as it is available?

The honorable senator's question, of course, involves Government policy in the shipping field and it is not usual to answer questions concerning policy at question time. I suggest that the honorable senator place his question on the notice paper, and we shall in due course obtain for him the information he requires.

I preface my question to the Minister in Charge of Commonwealth Activities in Education and Research by commending him for his announcement yesterday of the increases in the number of later year scholarships, so that open entrance, later year and mature age university scholarships will reach 8,000, and post-graduate scholarships will be increased to 500. I also commend the Minister for promising a substantial increase in the allowance to scholarship holders which will cost, I believe, an additional $1,283,000 in a full year. The onlydifficulty in all this is -
Order! I ask the honorable senator to direct his question.

My question relates to booklet " The Commonwealth Government in Education" of July 1966. The booklet is fast becoming out of date because of the great strides in education grants being promised by the Government. Will the Minister consider having printed certain inserts for inclusion in the booklet where the figures contained therein are now out of date?

There is no doubt that from time to time figures relating to living the numbers of scholarships available and to allowances—indeed , over the whole field of education—will be superseded because of the advances which are being made and the increased amounts which are being given by the Commonwealth Governinent. I do not know whether on each occasion it will be possible or feasible to have inserts printed for inclusion in a booklet which is designed to show the situation at a given point of time. I would think that those persons specifically interested in the matter and having the booklet might perhaps themselves more easily make alterations as they become necessary. From an official publication point of view, it may be simpler if the booklet were changed only once a year, or at intervals of about that length.

I address the following questions to the Minister for Works: Has a private contract been let to a building firm for the construction of a new military camp at Holsworthy? Is the Minister aware of reports that, as a result of maladministration of the work involved, amongst other things whole brick walls totalling thousands of bricks have been pulled down days after their erection because they were built in the wrong place, hundreds of yards of drain age have had to be dug up because the contractors never packed the original pipes in sand, and one building had to have its doorways widened days after their completion by the bricklayers because the door openings were too small for the prefabricated steel door frames? Can the Minister say whether the contract is for a fixed amount or whether a rise and fall clause is included in its terms? What super vision of the work carried out is exercised by the Department? Will the Minister inquire into the allegations of maladministration and, if they are found proved, take steps that will eliminate this gross wastage of public funds?

I do not know whether the honorable senator purports to be allying himself with the charges that he has just mentioned or whether he is asking whether they are true. These charges have been brought to my attention before. It is worthy of note that they appeared initially in a publication which was issued by the site committee of the unions that are working at Holsworthy camp.
They appeared also in the Sydney Press.

Of course they did. The Sydney Press reproduced what was initially in the publication that was put out by the site committee of the unions that are working at the Holsworthy camp. It is also worthy of note that there has been for some time, and there continues to be, a dispute between the unions working at the Holsworthy site and the contractor, re volving around a demand on the part of the unions for a site allowance which has been refused by a Conciliation Commissioner and, on appeal, by a higher authority. Both those things should be kept in mind when considering these allegations which initially were, and up to this date have been, put forward without any specific case to support them but only in a general sort of way. The matter has been brought to my attention. The Department of Works has informed me that on this site there have been no more than the usual number of things that occur on a big construction job, and which are not at all unknown and are usually put right at the expense of the con tractor. The information furnished to me indicates that there will be no loss of money to the Commonwealth and no loss of time on the job. With that background, honorable senators might be able to assess for themselves the truth of this charge.

talker.name: MURPHY, the Hon. Lionel Keith, QC
Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: I ask the Minister for Supply what is being done by his Department to encourage the expansion of the Australian aircraft industry.

The Government Aircraft Factory is building the Mirage aircraft in Australia under licence and the Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation Pty. Ltd. is building the Macchi aircraft under licence from an Italian firm. Because of the experience that is being gained in modification and development, the building of those two aircraft is of considerable value to the Australian industry. Yesterday I was asked a question about the giving of assistance to the light aircraft industry. I said in reply that this matter was currently before the Tariff Board. I said also that the Victa Aviation Division was engaged in building a light trainer aircraft which had proved to be very successful and was being used by a number of flying clubs. As I said, at the present time this organisation has an application for assistance before the Tariff Board.

I direct to the Minister for Customs and Excise a question which might also concern the Minister for Trade and Industry. Has the Minister's attention been directed to a segment of a recent " Four Corners" television programme showing articles of children's clothing made from highly inflammable materials now being sold in Sydney stores? Has the Minister or his Department discussed this subject with importers or representatives of the textile industry? If not will he investigate the matter with a view to protecting the public?
I shall certainly make inquiries on the subject matter raised by the honorable senator. I hope to be in a position to make a comment with more particularity, perhaps tomorrow.

Will the Minister for Customs and Excise advise whether parcels containing second hand clothes and sweets forwarded by residents of Holland to relatives living in Australia are now subject to customs duty? If this is the case, will the Minister advise when duties on this class of goods first became payable and the nature of gifts not subject to customs duty that can still be forwarded by persons overseas to relatives living in Australia?

I must confess that the honorable senator read that question rather too quickly for me. As a general rule, used clothing would not be subject to duty. I need to have notice of any question asked as to the rates of duty on any particular article, If the honorable senator will put the question on the notice paper I shall have a departmental reply made available to him without delay.

I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. On 3rd May the Minister informed me by letter that the National Fitness Council intended producing a book let for general consumption on exercise and diet, but he was unable to indicate when this booklet would be available for distribution. In view of the lapse of time since then, can the Minister now indicate when this publication will be available?
I do not know when the booklet will be available, but I shall certainly inquire from the Minister for Health and advise the honorable senator.

I firect a question to the Minister representing the Minister for National Development. Is the Minister aware that there are large deposits of nickel ore on the border of Western Australia and South Australia? Is he aware that these large deposits are held by an overseas company? Is he aware that some two to three months ago 500 tons of this ore was shipped from the port of Adelaide overseas for treatment or testing? Did the overseas company which exported the ore obtain the permission of the Federal Minister responsible and/or the State Minister responsible? Is it the practice of the Australian Governmen' to allow the export of Australian ore overseas without permission?

I can think of a number of reasons why small shipments such as that to which the honorable senator refers would be sent Overseas. It could be sent overseas for testing for all types of things. I do not know of the position in this instance. For that reason I ask the honorable senator to put the question on the notice paper. The only nickel deposits in Western Australia of which I have know ledge are those which, I understand, come under the direction of the Western Mining Corporation which, I read, is developing a mine. That is the only one of which I know. If the honorable senator will put the question on the notice paper I shall get the information for him from the Minister for National Development.

I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Will the Prime Minister discuss with other Ministers the matter of questions asked by senators, and will he request Ministers to treat with respect questions which genuinely seek information? Does the Prime Minister consider it correct to decide that no answer is needed to a question seeking information which is not generally known?

I think the honorable senator and indeed all honorable senators will be aware that the discretion is left with the Minister concerned to decide whether or not to answer a question. But I am quite confident that any Minister of this Government, if he felt that a question was being asked genuinely for information purposes, would want to do everything possible to get the information for the senator who asked the question.

talker.name: MURPHY, the Hon. Lionel Keith, QC
Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: I wish to direct a question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, who is also the Minister representing the Minister for Labour and National Service. Will the Government consider remitting to unions the loss suffered through the Government's failure to perform its promise of May 1965 to make regulations to prevent, except in special circumstances, the award of the costs of more than one counsel in penal proceedings?

The honorable senator is clearly asking a question about policy and it is not the practice to answer such questions. I seem to recollect that he asked a similar question before, claiming that a promise had been broken. I did not accept that then and I do not accept it or reject it now.

talker.name: MURPHY, the Hon. Lionel Keith, QC
Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: I asked why the promise had been broken.
When the honorable senator asked why a promise had been broken he was assuming that it had been broken and I am not prepared at this stage to accept that.

I ask the Minister representing the Minister for External Affairs: What are the activities of the Commonwealth Government in the civil aid field in South Vietnam? How is the civil aid programme directed and co-ordinated?

The honorable senator's question should be placed on the notice paper because I would like to give him a full and detailed reply. I take it that the honorable senator would include in civil aid not only civil aid under the direction of civilians but also the work done by Australian Army troops in Vietnam—building schools, improving roads and helping life in the villages.
Civil aid comprehensively.
I will get the information for the honorable senator.

Can the Minister representing the Treasurer say when the next refund of surplus superannuation money will be made? Is the refund to be free of income tax? If the refund is to be tax free, will the Treasurer issue instructions that a credit be made to those taxpayers who have already paid income tax on past refunds?

I know that the Treasurer has been pressing for another payment to be made, but I do not know what stage has been reached in this matter at the moment. I suggest that the honorable senator put his question on the notice paper and I will get the information for him.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister re presenting the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice -

item.para: Will the Minister inquire into and advise the Senate of reasons for the cancellation of TransAustralia Airlines 10 a.m. service to Wynyard and Devonport on Saturday, 20th August 1966, five minutes prior to the scheduled time of departure?

Is it a fact that 20 or more passengers booked on this service for the north west coast had to pro ceed to Launceston, thence by road transport, in some cases, for some 90 miles, occasioning them considerable inconvenience, while the AnsettA.N.A. service to this area proceeded as scheduled?
Why did the T.A.A. aircraft not land at Devonport despite the fact that it flew over the airport?
Why was the T.A.A. 10 a.m. service to Launceston scheduled for Friday, 19th August 1966 cancelled, while the Ansett-A.N.A. service proceeded as usual?
Are insufficient suitable aircraft available to T.A.A. to enable that airline to meet its business requirements? If so, what steps arc being taken to overcome these problems?

talk.start.para: The Minister for Civil Aviation has supplied the following answers to the honorable senator's questions -

item.para: Flight 567, Melbourne-Wynyard-Devonport, was cancelled on Saturday, 20th August, due to the unavailability of an aircraft arising from the unserviceability of a B727 aircraft.

The 29 passengers booked on the flight were carried to Launceston on Flight 447 and thence to their destination by road transport. The loadings on the Ansett-A.N.A. service prevented TransAustralia Airlines making use of that service, but 20 passengers booked Devonport-Melbourne on the return flight were transferred to Ansett-A.N.A

The diversion of the Melbourne-Launceston flight into Devonport would have delayed the return flight by about 45 minutes and resulted in missed connections for passengers on that flight which was fully booked from Launceston.

Flight 447 Melbourne-Launceston on Friday, 19th August was cancelled due to the unavailability of an aircraft. This occurred due to a delay to Flight 598 ex Hobart arising from crew rest requirements following a late arrival on the previous night and also to fog at Launceston where Flight 578 was scheduled to call.
T.A.A. has sufficient aircraft to meet normal requirements but sometimes experiences shortages at peak times or when first fine equipment becomes unavailable due to planned or unplanned situations.

talk.start.para: . - On 25th August 1966, Senator Laught asked me the following question -

quote.para: The Postmaster-General announced on 15th August that a new microwave trunk system was brought into operation between Adelaide and Melbourne on that day and that he expected to introduce limited subscriber trunk dialling over the route in November. Will the Minister ascertain from his colleague, first, what section of Adelaide subscribers will constitute the initial group and, secondly, in what order subsequent groups will be granted this excellent facility?

question.para: The Postmaster-General has now furnished me with the following information in reply -

item.para: The initial introduction of limited subscriber trunk dialling from Adelaide to Melbourne will serve all subscribers in the central city area of Adelaide, whose telephone numbers commence with 8, 51 and 23. About 12,000 subscribers are involved.

Current planning envisages that, following the installation of modern trunk switching equipment in Adelaide, further extension of the S.T.D. service will be possible in about two years from now. At that stage, all subscribers served by exchanges which are technically suitable for S.T.D. operation will be afforded the facility. Although it is not possible to be firm at the present time, it is expected that the Edwardstown, Unley, Woodville, Henley Beach, St. Mary's, Hampstead, Modbury, Paradise and Brighton exchanges will be included. All subscribers with S.T.D. service at that stage will be able to dial direct not only to Melbourne but also to a number of additional centres, yet to be determined, both in South Australia and other States.

talk.start.para: .- On 25th August, Senator Webster asked me the following question, without notice -

quote.para: Can the Minister representing the Postmaster-General inform the Senate of the time that is allotted by commercial broadcasting stations in Australia to the broadcasting of music which is the work of Australian composers as required by section 114 (2) of the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942-1965?

question.para: The Postmaster-General has now furnished me with the following information in reply -

quote.para: Section 114 (2) of the Act provides -

Not less than five per centum of the time occupied by the programmes of the Commission, and not less than five per centum of the time occupied by the programmes of a commercial broadcasting station, in the broadcasting of music shall be devoted to the broadcasting of works of composers who are Australians.

Figures received from the Australasian Performing Right Association show that the average use of Australian compositions by the commercial stations during the year ended 30th June, 1966, was 6.52 per cent. of the total time devoted to music. For the previous twelve months the figure was 6.40 per cent.

debateinfo.title: SCIENCE LABORATORIES AND APPARATUS IN SECONDARY SCHOOLS.

talk.start.para: -(Victoria; Minister for Works and Minister in Charge of Commonwealth Activities in Education and Research). - by leave - .I can now provide a table giving information as to which schools in which States and in what years of the present triennium 1965-1968 are to receive assistance for the provision of science teaching facilities. The lists which I have circulated give 'details about individual assisted schools as at 3 1st August 1966. I last provided honorable senators with information about the progress of the scheme on 28th April 1966.

speech.para: The amount available to States for expenditure on State schools during the two years from 1st July .1964 to 30th June 1966 amounted to $14,475,600. Of this amount the States spent $14,205,200. The remaining $270,400 is available for expenditure during this, and the next, financial year. A further $14,475,600 has been appropriated for the States for this purpose for the financial years 1966-67 and 1967-68. Since the beginning of this financial year the States have requested, and received, out of the $7,237,800 appropriated to them during 1966-67 plus the $270,400 carried forward from 1965-66, advances totalling $800,000. During the period from 1st July 1964 to 31st August 1966 expenditure under the programme has resulted in the construction of science laboratories, including multi-laboratory science blocks, in 228 State secondary schools throughout Australia.

In the case of independent schools in the States $5,336,000 was available during the two years from 1st July 1964 to 30th June 1966, and of this amount the State Governments were authorised to pay $5,177,924 to independent schools. The remaining $30,668 is available for expenditure during this and the next financial year. The amount of $5,177,924, together with money added by the independent schools themselves, resulted in 328 independent secondary schools either building or equipping laboratories, or both building and equipping laboratories during the two year period.

In addition, a further $5,336,000 has been appropriated for the use of independent secondary schools in the States during 1966-67 and 1967-68. As at 31st August 1966, independent schools have received, out of the $2,668,000 appropriated for 1966- 67, plus the $30,668 carried forward from 1965-66, payments totalling $1,762,110. In addition, a further seven independent schools in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory have received assistance for science laboratories and equipment. In the period from 1st July 1964 to 31st August 1966, they had received $349,936 against a total approved programme amounting to $563,216.

In total, therefore, 563 secondary schools benefited from the scheme up to 30th June 1966; the degree of benefit varying from the building of multi-laboratory science blocks to the provision of apparatus for one laboratory. As well, practically every State secondary school in Australia in which science is taught is receiving some science teaching equipment, including items for new curricula and other important items of apparatus which would not otherwise be available to such schools.

During the two year period 1966-67 and 1967- 68 a further 179 independent schools will receive assistance. The number of State schools to be assisted during 1966-67 and 1967-68 will be determined by the States in the course of developing their overall works programmes.
